According to this section of the regulation, if any one of the regulated flammable compounds is present above one weight percent in the mixture, the entire weight of the mixture must be considered when establishing the total process quantity for RMP-applicability purposes.  Zofness Station contains 70,459 lbs. of condensate which exceeds the 10,000 lb applicability threshold for flammable mixtures.  Since the RMP applicability is triggered, the Station is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention rule and must prepare an RMP.

1.2. RMP REQUIERMENTS

All facilities subject to the RMP rule must complete a hazard assessment analysis for the regulated chemical. In addition, the recent (5-year) accident history and emergency response plan must be reviewed. Based on these assessments, the Station will be classified within one of three program levels.



>    Program 1 - no offsite receptor impacted (potentially and in last five years)

>    Program 2 - offsite impacts and not subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration Process Safety Management Standard (OSHA PSM)

>    Program 3 - offsite impacts and subject to OSHA PSM    



All programs require submittal of an RMPlan. For Program 2 and 3 processes, two additional tasks are required: a release prevention program and an emergency response program. The following sections provide a brief summary of the hazard assessment, accident history, prevention program, emergency response, and subsequent RMP program level determination for the Zofness Station.

1.3. HAZARD ASSESSMENT

Three potential release scenario of condensate were identified as having the largest potential impact, should a release occur: the inlet slug catcher tank rupture, the truck loading leaking, and the process piping rupture. The rupture of the inlet slug catcher tank was identified to be the worst-case release scenario since it will result the largest release quantity. Fo

r the worst-case release scenario, the maximum distance to the level of concern is 0.3 miles. Details on the hazard assessment are provided in Section 2.

1.4. RECEPTORS IMPACTED

Once the impact distance of the worst-case release scenario is examined, the impact on off-site receptors must be considered. If public receptors   or environmental receptors   are impacted, additional analysis is required. The level of concern (0.3 miles) extends past the fence line to off-site locations, and any unrestricted areas within this region must be evaluated to determine if public or environmental receptors are impacted. There are no environmental receptors within the impact radius. Details on the receptors impacted are provided in Section 2.3.

1.5. PROGRAM LEVEL

Condensate storage at the Zofness Station qualifies as a Program 2 process since, based on the offsite consequence analysis, the maximum distance to the level of concern impacts public receptors and the process is not subject to the OSHA process safety management standard (29 CFR ?1910.19).  







 

2. HAZARD ASSESSMENT 

2.1. POTENTIAL RELEASE SCENARIO ANALYSIS



A "worst-case release" is defined under 40 CFR ?68.3 as:



"... the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint defined in 40 CFR ?68.22(a)."



The worst-case scenario quantity is determined in 40 CFR ?68.25(b) as the greatest amount in any single vessel or pipe used in a covered process, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity.



The term "process" is defined in 40 CFR ?68.3 as:



"... any activity involving a regulated substance including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site movement of such substances, or combination of these activities. For the purposes of this definition, any group of vessels that are interconnected, or separate vessels that are located such that a regulated substance could

be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process."



The definition of "process" is broad and can be interpreted to include all equipment handling a regulated substance.  Three main processes at the Zofness Station have the potential to release a regulated substance. These include:

1. Inlet slug catcher tank rupture;

2. Leaking during truck loading operations; 

3. Process piping rupture. 

2.1.1. Inlet Slug Catcher Tank Rupture

The largest condensate storage tank is the largest process vessel and is filled to a maximum of 12,600 gallons.  Should a spill occur, all of 12,600 gallons of natural gas condensate is assumed to be released in the worst-case release scenario.  Assuming the vessel is filled to 12,600 gallons with natural gas liquids with a specific gravity of 0.67, the maximum release quantity would be 70,459 lbs. 

2.1.2. Truck Loading Leaking

The leaking of condensate from truck loading hoses and connectors is another major potential release scenario with a release resulting from a transfer hose breakage at a truck loading rate of 4.5 barrel/min.  Based on information provided by operations personnel, response time has been estimated at 1 minute.  This is based on the time would take the loading operator to shut down the loading operation upon discovery of the release.  The total release of condensate is calculated as 1,057 lbs with detailed calculations shown in section 2.4.2.  

 

2.1.3. Process Piping Rupture

For purposes of the alternative analysis, the rupture of process piping which would lead to a release is assumed to consist of a 50 lb/min release of natural gas liquids (methane) for 30 minutes. The total release of natural gas liquids in this case is 1,500 lbs.  The release from the piping system is discussed in detail in the alternative scenarios.



Since the corresponding volume of release from the inlet slug catcher tank is larger than the piping rupture, and truck loading/unloading leaking, the rupture o

f the inlet slug catcher tank is determined to be the worst-case process for the Zofness Station.

2.2. WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO ANALYSIS

For the worst-case scenarios, RMP*Comp simply requires the input of the compounds involved in the release, and their quantities.  The largest condensate storage tank rupture is assumed to be the worst-case release scenario.  It is noted that this vessel does not operate with full liquid levels under normal, or even foreseeable conditions.  The RMP regulation allows a reduction in the worst-case release quantities below maximum vessel capacities if documented administrative controls are in place to limit vessel inventories.  However, for purposes of conservatism, the Zofness Station has assumed that the vessel would be filled to a maximum of 12,600 gallons at the time of a worst-case accidental release situation. Assuming the vessel is filled to 12,600 gallons with natural gas liquids with a specific gravity of 0.67, the maximum release quantity would be 70,459 lbs.

2.2.2. Dispe

rsion Modeling Analysis

The dispersion modeling analysis for accidental condensate release into the ambient air is evaluated with the RMP*Comp program (Version 2.01).  The software computes the distance to the applicable "endpoints", which are the damage thresholds specified within the RMP regulation.  For the worst-case vapor cloud explosion, the endpoint distance is 1.0 psi explosion overpressure.  This level of overpressure is considered to be the lower threshold of significant damage to most wood-frame structures, within which offsite residents could be seriously injured.  Beside the release and meteorological conditions discussed above, the analysis also utilized the rural ground surface roughness.  The modeled Distance-To- Endpoint was 0.3 miles, regardless of whether the accidental release is considered as the mixture of ethane, butane, methane, pentane and propane.  The detailed RMP*Comp output listing for the worst case scenario is included in Appendix A.

2.3. OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT

After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule.  The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the flammable endpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.



MARPLOT (Mapping Applications for Response, Planning, and Local Operational Tasks, Version 4.2.4) was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identi

fy public receptors.  MARPLOT provides databases from the Bureau of Census, and other federal agencies.  The demographic information in MARPLOT is based on the 2010 Census. 



MARPLOT shows that no population is within the 0.3 mile impact radius for the worst case release.  The impact areas on a MARPLOT map is demonstrated in Figure 1 in Appendix B.  The satellite view of impacted area is illustrated by Google Earth (Version 7.1.2.2041) and is shown in Figure 2 in Appendix B.  The types of public receptors   and environmental receptors   identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-3.  As can be seen from Figure 1, within the 0.3 mile distance of the largest storage tank there are offsite residences as public receptors.  Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.

2.4. ALTERNATIVE SCENARIO RELEASE ANALYSIS 

2.4.1. Release from Process Piping

For alternative release scenarios, leaking of condensate from process piping rupture was considered to be modeled.  The rate of release was assumed to be 50 lb/min and the duration of release was assumed to be 30 minutes.  The total release of natural gas condensate was calculated as 1,500 lbs. 



For purposes of the RMP*Comp calculations, natural gas is assumed to consist of 100% methane.  The modeled vapor cloud effect zone represents the dispersion distance to the lower flammabilit

y limit (LFL) of methane (5% by volume in air).  The meteorological parameters for the alternative scenario are defined by 40 CFR ?68.28(b) as having a wind speed of 3 m/s and the atmospheric stability Class D with an ambient temperature of 25 ?C.  Beside the release and meteorological conditions, the analysis also utilized the rural ground surface roughness.  The scenario is not expected to occur, but is more likely than that worst-case vapor cloud explosion scenario described above.  The modeled Distance-To-Endpoint was 0.1 mile.  The detailed RMP*Comp output listing for the alternative scenario is included in Appendix A.



After the distance to the toxic endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. MARPLOT (Version 4.2.4) is used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  As can be seen from the map, the distance to the nearest public receptor is beyond the 0.1 mile distance to the level of concern.  Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the alternative release scenario.

2.4.2. Release from Truck Loading

Another alternative release scenario, leaking of condensate from failing truck loading hoses and connectors was considered to be modeled.  The rate of release is assumed to be the same as loading rate (4.5 barrel/min) and the duration of release is assumed to be the time needed to deploy shutdown measures, which is 1 minute.  This is based on the time would take the loading operator to shut down the loading operation from the discovery of the release.  The total release of condensate is calculated as 1,057 lbs with detailed calculation shown below.



(4.5 barrel/min)* (42gallon/barrel)*(8.34 lb/gallon)* (0.6705)*(1 min) = 1,056.9 lbs



From the results of these calculations, the dispersion modeling analysis for the alternative scenario related

to an accidental release into the ambient air is evaluated with the RMP*Comp program (Version 2.01).  The meteorological parameters for the alternative scenario are defined by 40 CFR ?68.28(b) as having a wind speed of 3 m/s and the atmospheric stability Class D with an ambient temperature of 25 ?C.  Beside the release and meteorological conditions, the analysis also utilized the rural ground surface roughness.  The modeled Distance-To- Endpoint is 0.1 mile.  The detailed RMP*Comp output listing for the alternative scenario is included in Appendix A.



After the distance to the toxic endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. MARPLOT (Version 4.2.4) is used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the toxic endpoint and to identify public receptors.  As can be seen from the map, no public and environmental receptors are impacted by the alternative release scenario.

3. PREVENTION PROGRAM

Zofness Station has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. The Zofness Station was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME standards. The following section briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at the Zofness Station.

3.1. SAFETY INFORMATION

Zofness Station maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes.  All chemical substances present at the site are identified and Material Safety Sheets (MSDS) are available for each employee to review.  Maximum intended inventory of equipment in which the regulated substances are stored or processed are compiled and maintained at the site. The codes and standards that relied upon for design were based on best engineering knowledge and judgment, Based on

past satisfactory performance in the expected range of operating conditions, it has been determined that the design and construction of equipment and piping is suitable for current intended use.

3.2. HAZARD REVIEW

Zofness Station conducted a comprehensive Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation on November 2014 to ensure that hazards associated with processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) method was used in conducting the PHA. The HAZOP study was carried out in a number of HAZOP study sessions and was undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and will be revalidated at an interval of five years.  Any findings related to the hazard analyses will be addressed in a timely manner.  The PHA report is included in Appendix F.

3.3. OPERATING PROCEDURES

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, Zofness Station maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround. This information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

3.4. TRAINING

Zofness Station has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

3.5. MAINTENANCE

The Station carries out highly documented inspections and maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined during these checks includes, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Inspection and maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with

previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by these checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

3.6. COMPLIANCE AUDITS

Zofness Station conducted a compliance audit on April 2014 to determine whether the provisions set out under RMP rule are being implemented. These audits will be carried out at least every three years and any corrective actions required as a result of audits will be undertaken in a safe prompt manner. The report from the latest compliance audit is included in Appendix G.

3.7. INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

No incident has occurred in the past five years at the Zofness Station.  Zofness Station promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the circumstances leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions needed to prevent the incident from reoccurring. All reports will be retained for a minimum of five years.

3.8. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Zofness Station maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental release of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. To ensure proper functioning, the emergency response plan was recently updated in August 2014.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response.



    

     

4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENTAL HISTORY

Per the requirements of the RMP rule, Zofness Station must include a five-year accident history in the Risk Management Plan. The five-year accident history involves an examination of the effects of any accid

ental releases of one or more of the regulated substances from a covered process in the five years prior to the submission of the Risk Management Plan. To be reportable, the release must have caused at least one of the following:





1.    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or

2.    Known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.



No accidental release has occurred in the past five years at the Zofness Station. 

5. RMPLAN SUBMITTAL

Submittal of an RMPlan is required for all covered processes for which a regulated substance is above a threshold quantity in a process.     A completed RMPlan registration is included in Appendix A. In addition, the certification letter to be included with the RMPlan submittal is provided in Appendix B.  Since condensate stored in the Zofness Station falls within the limits of the Program 2 requirements, the RMPlan will contain the information pertinent to this program.



Upon submittal of the RMPlan, no additional submittals will be required by Zofness Station under RMP until:





1.    An condensate release accident with offsite impacts occurs;

2.    Process changes might reasonably be expected to change the distance to the level of concern by a factor of two or more;

3.    A change occurs at or near Station that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis (eg. new public receptors become present within the impact radius, or;

4.    Five years from the anniversary date of RMPlan renewal.  





The certification letter and the electronic diskette should be submitted through RMP*eSubmit.
